news.title: Voters may be rethinking everything: 2028 US Presidential polls reveal a stunning shift
news.text:
AP2028 US Presidential polls

US Presidential 2028 polls: The 2028 US presidential election may still be years away, but early polling suggests voters are already challenging long-held assumptions about who could lead the next race for the White House.Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez vs JD Vance: A Close 2028 MatchupA recent poll by The Argument/Verasight shows Democratic Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez holding a narrow edge over Republican Vice President JD Vance in a hypothetical 2028 presidential matchup, as per a report. The survey found Ocasio-Cortez leading Vance 51% to 49%, as per a SILive.com report.The difference falls within the poll‚Äôs 2.7% margin of error, meaning the two candidates are statistically tied. While, the result is striking given that Vance is widely viewed as the frontrunner for the Republican nomination, while Ocasio-Cortez represents the progressive wing of the Democratic Party.The survey was conducted between December 5 and December 11 and included responses from 1,521 registered voters, offering an early glimpse into how fluid and unpredictable the 2028 presidential race may become.Also read: Stock market today: S&P 500, Dow, Nasdaq rise as AI stocks rebound ‚Äì here's why Oracle, Nvidia, and Micron led gainsLive EventsWhat the 2028 Poll Asked VotersThe poll asked registered voters who they would support if Vance and Ocasio-Cortez were the major-party nominees. The close result suggests the 2028 open-seat race could be highly competitive and that neither party currently holds a clear advantage, as per the SILive.com report.Voter Divide Emerges Across Demographic GroupsThe findings also highlight sharp divides among voting groups. Vance performed better among white voters, with 57% saying they would support him compared with 43% for Ocasio-Cortez. By contrast, Ocasio-Cortez showed strong support among Black voters, with 79% backing her, and Hispanic voters, where she led with 64%.Also read: DOJ releases new Jeffrey Epstein files today: Here's what's inside the latest trove of Department of Justice documentsJD Vance Seen as GOP Front-Runner for 2028Vance is considered the favorite for the 2028 GOP nomination, with US president Donald Trump previously saying that Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio would make a strong Republican ticket. Trump himself is barred from seeking another term under the 22nd Amendment to the US Constitution.JD Vance Seen as GOP Front-Runner for 2028Ocasio-Cortez has also been mentioned as a possible contender for the Democratic nomination. While she polls well with younger voters, broader surveys show her trailing California Governor Gavin Newsom and former Vice President Kamala Harris in most 2028 matchups, as per the SILive.com report.Betting Markets Add to 2028 Election BuzzGamblers placing legal bets on the race have long viewed Vance and Newsom as the leading contenders for their respective party nominations, as per the report.FAQsWhat does the latest 2028 poll show?It shows Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez narrowly leading JD Vance in a hypothetical matchup.Who conducted this 2028 election poll?The survey was carried out by The Argument/Verasight.Add as a Reliable and Trusted News Source Add Now!

news.summary: US Presidential 2028 polls: Early 2028 presidential polling indicates a statistically tied hypothetical matchup between Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and JD Vance, with Ocasio-Cortez holding a narrow 51% to 49% lead. The poll, conducted by The Argument/Verasight, highlights significant demographic divides, with Vance leading among white voters and Ocasio-Cortez strong with Black and Hispanic voters.

news.title: Elise Stefanik drops out of N.Y. governor's race 6 weeks after bid
news.text:
Dec. 19 (UPI) -- enRepublican U.S. House Rep. Elise Stefanik on Friday announced she was ending her run for New York governor after 1 1/2 months and won't seek another term in Congress.

On Nov. 7, On Nov. 7, Stefanik launched a campaign bid in an effort to challenge Democratic Gov. Kathy Hochul in November 2026.

"While spending precious time with my family this Christmas season, I have made the decision to suspend my campaign for Governor and will not seek re-election to Congress," Stefanik, 41, wrote on X. "I did not come to this decision lightly for our family.

"I am truly humbled and grateful for the historic and overwhelming support from Republicans, Conservatives, Independents, and Democrats all across the state for our campaign to Save New York."

Stefanik is married to Matthew Manda, who works in marketing and communication, and they have a 4-year-old son.

"And while many know me as Congresswoman, my most important title is Mom," she wrote. "I believe that being a parent is life's greatest gift and greatest responsibility. I have thought deeply about this and I know that as a mother, I will feel profound regret if I don't further focus on my young son's safety, growth, and happiness - particularly at his tender age."

Her main primary opposition was Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman, who announced his run 10 days ago.

"However, as we have seen in past elections, while we would have overwhelmingly won this primary, it is not an effective use of our time or your generous resources to spend the first half of next year in an unnecessary and protracted Republican primary, especially in a challenging state like New York," Stefanik wrote.

The last Republican governor in New York was George Pataki, who served three terms from 1995 to 2006.

The last time a Republican presidential candidate won New York was in 1984, when incumbent Ronald Reagan defeated Democrat Walter Mondale.

Former Vice President Kamala Harris won the state by 13 points, down from former President Joe Biden's 23-point victory in 2000.

"Elise Stefanik has finally acknowledged reality: If you run against Governor Kathy Hochul, you are going to lose," Hochul spokesperson Ryan Radulovacki told Politico. "As Donald Trump raises costs on New Yorkers and targets this state relentlessly, Governor Hochul has cut middle-class taxes, put money back in New Yorkers' pockets, and fought this administration and won when New York has come under attack."

Stefanik has represented the rural conservative upstate New York district since 2014, becoming the youngest woman ever elected to Congress at that time.

The 21st Congressional District covers the northernmost part of the state, bordering Canada to the north and Vermont to the east. Major cities include Plattsburgh, Watertown, Glens Falls, Ogdensburg and Rome.

In November 2024, she was overwhelmingly re-elected by 24 percentage points as Trump carried the conservative region by more than 20 points.

When President Trump was elected president last November, he nominated her to serve as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. But the nomination was pulled because of the narrow Republican edge in the House, with Trump saying it was "essential that we maintain EVERY Republican seat in Congress."

Hochul would have called for a special election.

Republicans now have a 220-213 advantage with two vacancies in seats by Democrats who have died.

Stefanik rose in House leadership, serving as the fourth-ranking House Republican, a position she first attained in May 2021 by replacing Liz Cheney. She was succeeded in this specific role by Lisa McClain for the 119th Congress.

After her nomination was pulled, Speaker Mike Johnson named her chairwoman of House Republican Leadership.

She originally was a critic of Trump but became one of his most vocal allies.

Stefanik fell a little out of favor with the president after she called New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani a "jihadist."

During a meeting with Mamdan in the White House, the president reduced to label the Democratic socialist that description. He is a Muslim and South Asian.

Trump hadn't endorsed either candidate, including when Stefanik was in the White House's Oval Office when he signed legislation awarding the 1980 U.S. Olympic ice hockey team the Congressional Gold Medal. The teams won the gold medal in Lake Place, which includes Stefdanik's district.

Ed Cox, chairman of the New York Republican Party, endorsed Blackman after Stefanik's decision. In a statement, he also said Stefanik would "remain a leader in our party and a powerful voice for our principles. We respect her decision and thank her for her efforts."

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt served as Stefanik's communications director from 2020-23.

"Elise Stefanik has been an incredible advocate for the people of her district in Upstate New York, and she will always be a true friend to President Trump," she posted on X. "On a personal note, Elise is my former boss. She is a great leader, and an even better person. We love you, posted.
news.summary: Republican U.S. House Rep. Elise Stefanik announced she was ending her run for New York governor after 1 1/2 months and won't seek another term in Congress.
news.author: Allen Cone

news.title: List of Celebrities Mentioned in New Jeffrey Epstein Files
news.text: Every release of documents and photos related to Jeffrey Epstein has featured celebrities, and Friday's massive release is no different, with several celebrities being mentioned. Why It Matters The release of the Jeffrey Epstein files under the Epstein Files Transparency Act represents a pivotal moment in a case that has gripped public attention for years and has threatened the reputations of many famous people. President Donald Trump signed a mandate into law requiring the release of the files, and advocates argue that the historic release will offer Americans new insight into one of the most significant scandals involving sex trafficking and abuse of underage girls by powerful figures in business, science, politics, and entertainment. What To Know On Friday, the Department of Justice began releasing hundreds of thousands of files linked to Epstein, the financier whose connections with prominent individuals and criminal activities led to multiple federal probes and global headlines. The initial tranche includes emails, photographs, flight logs, and estate records. The law requires public disclosure of all unclassified Epstein-related records, with redactions for victims' identities and material tied to ongoing investigations. It should be noted that individuals named in the documents are not necessarily accused of wrongdoing. The files contain correspondence, travel logs, and social interactions, much of which has already been referenced in previous investigations or court proceedings. Many of those revealed as Epstein's associates have denied any knowledge or participation in his criminal activities. Among the public figures and celebrities named in the documents are: The inclusion of these names reflects a range of connections, from socializing and professional correspondence to private meetings. Many names, including Clinton and Trump, have appeared repeatedly in litigation and press coverage of the Epstein case. Epstein‚Äôs ties with high-profile figures span decades. Flight logs and emails reference attendees and guests at gatherings at his various properties. Documents include testimony from survivors, depositions with associates, and email exchanges with politicians and entrepreneurs. Some disclosures, such as photographs showing Trump, Clinton, and others, have been made public through Congressional committees and media investigations. Many of those named have issued prior statements denying any involvement in Epstein's crimes or knowledge of his activities. What People Are Saying Democratic Representative Ro Khanna, who sponsored the Epstein Files Transparency Act, told CBS News: ‚ÄúThe fact they are even releasing hundreds of thousands of these is a historic moment for survivors across our nation.‚Äú Former Vice President Kamala Harris voiced skepticism about the completeness of the release, telling Jimmy Kimmel: ‚ÄúThe agency has been treated 'like a personal law firm.'‚Äù Angel Ure√±a, spokesperson for former President Clinton, told The Guardian: ‚ÄúPresident Clinton knows nothing about the terrible crimes Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to in Florida some years ago, or those with which he has been recently charged in New York.‚Äù What Happens Next The Department of Justice plans to continue releasing additional documents in accordance with the Epstein Files Transparency Act. Survivors‚Äô advocates continue to call for full transparency, while several named individuals may face renewed scrutiny regarding the nature of their interactions with Epstein. Congressional oversight committees are expected to review the redaction process and may call additional witnesses. The Justice Department is required by law to submit to Congress a list of any redacted or withheld documents within 15 days of public release and is prohibited from withholding records exclusively for reasons of ‚Äòembarrassment or political sensitivity.‚Äô Update 12/19/25 5:50 p.m. ET: This article has been updated with additional information.
news.summary: Several celebrities were mentioned in the new Epstein documents released on Friday.
news.author: Jenni Fink,Peter Aitken

news.title: The Millennial Manifesto
news.text:
An amazing 8,000-word essay entitled The Lost Generation surfaced Monday in Compact Magazine by Jacob Savage, and is one of the most illuminating pieces I've read in years. I'm 59-years-old. I'm at the very front edge of the Gen X'ers, but I identify as a Baby Boomer. I missed the cut-off by about two years. I fully recognize that every generation, by the time they get to my advanced years, begins telling stories about how the generation following them just aren't the same as they were when they were growing up. With Millennials, I've discovered that this generational axiom has the added benefit of being true. Millennials have become the punchline of a lot of jokes. The rap on these current 28-44-year-olds are that they're lazier than the generation before them, not too motivated to make their own way in the world, very self-centered, and generally gloomy about what the future holds for them. My son is 35-years-old, right in the heart of this cohort of Americans, and just provided me with a year's worth of stand-up material with his pre-Thanksgiving trip to see me alone.After reading this Savage article, complete with tons of stats and anecdotes accumulated from tons of first-person interviews, I now understand why Millennials in general are the way they are. And there is a ton of opportunity for J.D. Vance in 2028, assuming he's the Republican nominee after Secretary of State Marco Rubio all but cleared the field. The article is about the incredible damage DEI policies have had on the employment prospects, and the resulting psychological impact, on Millennial white males trying to make their mark writing in the world of media. It's obviously a niche industry, but it's a microcosm of the ongoing devastation of DEI policies that took root during the Obama presidency and crescendoed after the death of George Floyd in 2020. Savage, a fledgling writer trying to break through writing television pilots and pitching them to studios to turn into series, tells this story. 

But of course, by 2016, we were already too late. The showrunner emailed us back apologetically. ‚ÄúI had initially thought I might be able to bring you guys on,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúbut in the end it wasn‚Äôt possible.‚Äù We met with the executive anyway‚Äîa Gen-X white guy‚Äîwho told us how much he loved our pilot. But the writers room was small, he explained apologetically, and the higher-level writers were all white men. They couldn‚Äôt have an all-white-male room. Maybe, if the show got another season, they‚Äôd be able to bring us on. They never did. The doors seemed to close everywhere and all at once. In 2011, the year I moved to Los Angeles, white men were 48 percent of lower-level TV writers; by 2024, they accounted for just 11.9 percent. The Atlantic‚Äôs editorial staff went from 53 percent male and 89 percent white in 2013 to 36 percent male and 66 percent white in 2024. White men fell from 39 percent of tenure-track positions in the humanities at Harvard in 2014 to 18 percent in 2023. In retrospect, 2014 was the hinge, the year DEI became institutionalized across American life.

Before you dismiss this as a lefty writer complaining that DEI policies he probably supported backfiring on him, this is a much, much bigger story than this one job market. Countless white males coming out of college or high school in the mid-10's, regardless of their political ideology, if they held any ideology at all, ran into a brick wall where career opportunities, and ultimately their chance at the American dream, were taken away from them for the sake of diversity hires. In 1974's Blazing Saddles, there was a scene where the railroad workers were brought in to cut a deal with the all-white residents of Rock Ridge to build a fake city in order to thwart the evil Hedley Lamarr, played by Harvey Korman. I'll clean up the language to make it FCC-compliant, but the offer by the townfolk was, "All right, we'll give land to the Blacks and the Asians, but we don't want the Irish." That wasn't an acceptable deal, and finally, everybody was included in the opportunity of a stake of land. That's what's happening here, except the Democrats who implemented DEI policies across education, law enforcement, law, and much of corporate America, still don't want the Irish. Whites need not apply. 

This may be how Boomer and Gen-X white men experienced DEI. But for white male millennials, DEI wasn‚Äôt a gentle rebalancing‚Äîit was a profound shift in how power and prestige were distributed. Yet practically none of the thousands of articles and think-pieces about diversity have considered the issue by cohort. This isn‚Äôt a story about all white men. It‚Äôs a story about white male millennials in professional America, about those who stayed, and who (mostly) stayed quiet. The same identity, a decade apart, meant entirely different professional fates. If you were forty in 2014‚Äîborn in 1974, beginning your career in the late-90s‚Äîyou were already established. If you were thirty in 2014, you hit the wall.

To those of us on the right, DEI was an issue that became a political bludgeon for Donald Trump, and as president, signed two executive orders to end wasteful DEI programs and preferences in government agencies, and another one to end illegal discrimination based on race and restroring merit-based opportunities in states and entities like colleges and universities that receive federal funding. It was a principled fight that Donald Trump campaigned on, and it was a promise on which he delivered. DEI certainly hit its peak in 2020 after George Floyd, but is sadly still far too entrenched in way too many sectors of the economy. What I failed to understand is not just what discrimination it did to conservatives trying to make their way in the world, but what it has done to disillusion 30-something males who might otherwise be liberals, but not so much anymore. From the tail end of Savage's piece, which I would recommend you read every word and share it with others: 

Most of the men I interviewed started out as liberals. Some still are. But to feel the weight of society‚Äôs disfavor can be disorienting. We millennials were true believers in race and gender-blind meritocracy, which for all its faults‚Äîits na√Øvet√© about human nature, its optimism in the American Dream‚Äîwas far superior to what replaced it. And to see that vision so spectacularly betrayed has engendered a skepticism toward the entire liberal project that won't soon disappear. ‚ÄúWhat troubles me is that a lot of thriving white millennial men have had to follow the Josh Hawley path, where you have to leave liberal America,‚Äù an old friend, the father of two biracial children, told me. ‚ÄúI don't want to do that. Liberal America is my home. But if everyone says, this is not the place for you, what are you supposed to do?‚Äù

Most of the men he interviewed started out as liberals. Some still are. My gracious, but what an opportunity that provides to expand the base. Donald Trump made huge inroads with labor union workers, with Blacks, Hispanics, surburban women, lots of voting blocs that typically vote Democratic, but got very turned off by Joe Biden's regency and Kamala Harris' ridiculous 107-day word salad tour. Inflation was killing them, and there was no one else to blame but Biden-Harris policies. And Trump, X and Truth Social warts and all, at least demonstrated he could generate a pretty prosperous economy the first time around, so he was the better choice in 2024. In all likelihood, Vice-President Vance is going to be the nominee. Secretary Rubio told Vanity Fair he's not running in 2028, and outside of a possible run by Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, the field is pretty open for Vance to get the nomination without too much trouble. On the Democratic side of the aisle, a knife fight is developing that should be hugely entertaining to watch. Former Transportation Secretary, Pothole Pete Buttigieg, wants a shot. Former Hillary Clinton and Obama senior staffer Rahm Emmanuel is going to get in. Gavin Newsom is running, both away from California and for the White House. There will be others. And as I wrote about earlier in the week, Axios is reporting that Kamala Harris is definitely gearing up for another run. Polling shows that among the Democratic potential contenders, Harris has a 11-point lead over her closest rival, Gavin Newsom. If the general election in November of 2028 turns into a Vance V. Harris contest, it will literally be a Millennial white male with the ability to articulate and communicate policies, and a vision for the future in a way the Republican Party hasn't seen since...ever. Ronald Reagan could communicate, he certainly had a vision for the future, but he wasn't in the age cohort of a field of voters Millennials make up that are currently available for harvest. Who would Vance be running against? Kamala Harris, who is literally and figuratively the embodiment of a DEI hire. She was chosen by Joe Biden to fulfill a promise of picking a Black female as his number two. Harris was not a merit-based pick. She was picked because she was thought by the Biden team to be the Black female that would do them the least harm. And she failed to cross even that low bar.

Job number one for whomever is running nationally for the Republicans, whether it's a Senate or House candidate in the midterms, or anyone running for the White House in '28, is to talk about the economy and affordability, and counter the narrative media and Democrats are spinning that we're in the worst economic environment ever becuase of Trump policies. Trump spoke to the nation Wednesday night and reeled off facts about job growth, lower energy costs, and how the housing market is improving now that illegal immigration is no longer creating an artificially high demand for units, driving up prices. All that is very good. But there's more that the next Republican for president, presumably Vance, needs to add to the agenda. The disillusionment on the left after what they believed in failed them makes these Millennial white males willing to listen, if Vance can resonate how the best way to achieve the equality they really want is equal access to opportunity, not government and corporations picking winners and losers based on skin color or gender in order to achieve equity. Replace the lost opportunies with words and actions to expand opportunities will reap electoral benefits to such a degree that Democrats won't know what hit them on Election Night. The Late Charlie Kirk used to be very, very good at that messaging to college-aged kids all over the country. He may have been the best in the conservative movement ever to be able to reason with young people, but a close second is Vance. When he spoke at a TPUSA event at Ole Miss a couple days before Halloween, it was a masterclass performance. The big question is will Vance, or someone around him, show him this Savage article, and will Vance grasp the political upside available to him and the skill set for communication he possesses? The good news is yes, he does. 

A lot of people think "DEI" is lame diversity seminars or racial slogans at NFL games. In reality, it was a deliberate program of discrimination primarily against white men. This is an incredible piece that describes the evil of DEI and its consequences:https://t.co/fMiIfvz0qz‚Äî JD Vance (@JDVance) December 17, 2025

There are lots of doomsayers on the right who think Republicans are headed for disaster in the midterms unless they get back to talking about the core issues of economics and affordability. That certainly needs to be the primary message. But there are millions of potential voters out there that the Democratic Party kicked to the curb who are persuadable, if somone just gives them attention, an ear, understanding, and most of all, hope for the future.
news.author: Duane Patterson

news.title: Rob Reiner's Death: Everything We Know So Far
news.text:
Rob Reiner, actor, director, writer, producer and actor, and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found murdered in their home on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025. The This Is Spinal Tap creator was 78. Singer Reiner was 68. Their son, Nick Reiner, was questioned and later arrested and charged with their slayings.

Here‚Äôs everything we know so far about the tragic loss of one of America‚Äôs most beloved filmmakers.

üé¨ SIGN UP for Parade‚Äôs Daily newsletter to get the latest pop culture news & celebrity interviews delivered right to your inbox üé¨

What happened to Rob Reiner?

Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner were found dead in their mansion in the Brentwood area of Los Angeles on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025.

The family said in a statement shortly after the news broke, ‚ÄúIt is with profound sorrow that we announce the tragic passing of Michele and Rob Reiner. We are heartbroken by this sudden loss, and we ask for privacy during this unbelievably difficult time.‚Äù

TMZ reported that their bodies were ‚Äúbutchered‚Äù and that sources described the scene as being the crimes of a ‚Äúmad man.‚Äù

The New York Times reported that investigators are still trying to determine the time of death, and that the Reiners may have been killed on Saturday, Dec. 13, 2025, or in the very early hours on Sunday.

TMZ reported that when the Reiners‚Äô bodies were discovered, rigor mortis had already set in, which usually begins between two and six hours after death.

Related: We Ranked Every Rob Reiner Movie‚ÄîHere‚Äôs the One That‚Äôs Still a Perfect 10

Who found Rob Reiner and his wife Michele Singer?

According to PEOPLE, Rob and Michele‚Äôs daughter Romy Reiner found her parents after they were murdered.

More details emerged in a report from the New York Times, which revealed that a massage therapist who was scheduled to be at the house called Romy when she couldn‚Äôt get in. Romy then went to the Reiners‚Äô family home, where she found her father‚Äôs body. She immediately left the premises and reportedly didn‚Äôt know her mother was also dead inside. She called police, then family friend Billy Crystal, who lived close by and came over to say a final farewell to his longtime collaborator and Michele.

On Wednesday, Dec. 17, 2025, Romy and her brother Jake Reiner released a statement about the slayings.

‚ÄúWords cannot even begin to describe the unimaginable pain we are experiencing every moment of the day,‚Äù they said. ‚ÄúThe horrific and devastating loss of our parents, Rob and Michele Reiner, is something that no one should ever experience. They weren‚Äôt just our parents; they were our best friends.‚Äù

They continued, ‚ÄúWe are grateful for the outpouring of condolences, kindness, and support we have received not only from family and friends but people from all walks of life. We now ask for respect and privacy, for speculation to be tempered with compassion and humanity, and for our parents to be remembered for the incredible lives they lived and the love they gave.‚Äù

Related: Why Rob Reiner Rejected the Title of ‚ÄòHero‚Äô Months Before His Death

What time were police called to Rob Reiner‚Äôs house?

Multiple reports state that paramedics and police were called to the Reiners‚Äô home between 3:30 p.m. and 3:40 p.m. PT on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025.

Where did Rob Reiner and Michele Singer live?

The Reiners lived in the wealthy enclave of Brentwood, located in the west side of Los Angeles county.

About 42,000 people reside in the neighborhood, including LeBron James, Gwyneth Paltrow, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Dr. Dre and Disney CEO Bob Iger, as well as former vice president Kamala Harris and former second gentleman Doug Emhoff. Other stars who‚Äôve lived in Brentwood include Marilyn Monroe, Bea Arthur, Betty White and O.J. Simpson.

Related: Billy Crystal and Larry David Seen at Rob Reiner‚Äôs Home After His Death

How did Rob Reiner die?

Both Rob and Michele Singer Reiner‚Äôs causes of deaths were homicide: They reportedly died after an assailant slit their throats. TMZ reported that the slayings took place after a ‚Äúheated argument‚Äù with their son Nick and that the bodies showed signs of ‚Äúlacerations consistent with a knife.‚Äù

Prosecutors in the case specified in their formal charging of Nick Reiner that a knife was used to commit the murders.

On Dec. 17, 2025, the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office released documents stating that the couple died from ‚Äúmultiple sharp force injuries,‚Äù the New York Post reported. They reportedly suffered from stab wounds to their throats as well as other parts on their bodies.

Related: Ron Howard Mourns Rob Reiner With Powerful Tribute Hours After His Death

Who killed Rob Reiner and his wife?

Nick Reiner, son of Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, was arrested in connection with their deaths, but is innocent until proven guilty.

Related: Nick Reiner Appears Unhappy in Photo With Parents 3 Months Before Tragedy

Who was the last person to talk to Rob Reiner?

While we don‚Äôt know the specific last person who spoke to Rob Reiner before his death, we do know that earlier that day and week, he was with friends and family who loved him.

Monty Python star Eric Idle said he spoke to Rob the day before the director was murdered.

‚ÄúRob Reiner was a lovely man. I spoke to him last night for over an hour,‚Äù Idle wrote on X (formerly Twitter) just after 1 a.m. PT on Monday, Dec. 15, 2025. ‚ÄúI always enjoyed his company. I met him at his Dad‚Äôs in 1975. He was telling me about fiming [sic] at Stonehenge and his thoughts for the future. This is so awful. I shall miss him. A clever, talented and very thoughtful man. So awful.‚Äù

Cinematographer Barry Markowitz told Page Six that he was likely one of the last people to see the Reiners alive, as he‚Äôd recently been staying with them in their Brentwood home. Markowitz said that the Reiners invited him to stay at their house when he was in town to promote one of his projects in November, and that at the time, it appeared Nick was ‚Äúon the upswing‚Äù with his health.

‚ÄúHe looked great. He was sitting and talking with the family,‚Äù Markowitz recalled. ‚ÄúThey eat dinner together, old school, and a lot of love, always a lot of love ‚Ä¶ He helped out, he took out the garbage, he watched TV, he washed dishes. He‚Äôd bring me something to drink. He was just normal in that sense.‚Äù

Markowitz said he didn‚Äôt notice anything unusual and that the family was loving and normal. When asked about what he thought of Nick‚Äôs alleged behavior and if he believed he could murder his own parents, he replied, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a sickness. That‚Äôs my verdict.‚Äù

Rob, Michele and Nick Reiner all attended pal Conan O‚ÄôBrien‚Äòs holiday party on Saturday, Dec. 13, 2025, TMZ reported. The three of them reportedly had a ‚Äúvery loud argument‚Äù at the soiree, after which Rob and Michele went home. Sources claimed that Michele was lamenting to friends that she and Rob were struggling for several months to get Nick treatment for his addiction and mental health problems.

Related: The Chilling Message Rob Reiner Told the World Months Before His Murder

Who is Nick Reiner?

Nick Reiner is the son of Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner. He was a screenwriter and worked with his father on the 2015 film Being Charlie, which was loosely autobiographical. He reportedly periodically Nick lived at home with his parents, and TMZ reported that Nick left the family home on his own accord before the slayings.

At one point, Nick worked as an intern for the long-running Seth Macfarlane animated comedy Family Guy.

‚ÄúHe was an intern on the show Family Guy for around three to six months. His father helped him get the gig,‚Äù a source told Page Six, adding that Rob ‚Äúwould drop him off‚Äù and ‚Äúpick him up‚Äù from the job daily. The insider claimed that Nick would work for about four hours a day, but that he did little actual work, instead spending the bulk of his time ‚Äúshooting the s**t‚Äù with his colleagues.

‚ÄúHe did not work hard and he wasn‚Äôt a hard worker,‚Äù the insider claimed. ‚ÄúHe was 100 percent entitled. There was really no responsibility for him because we didn‚Äôt have interns. It was a favor for Rob.‚Äù

The source called Nick ‚Äúcaptivating‚Äù and said he had a dark sense of humor.

‚ÄúHe was a funny kid. He was charismatic in a dark, introverted way. He was a goofy 20-year-old,‚Äù the insider said. ‚ÄúHe was the black sheep. He felt like a f**k up. He knew that. He was self-aware of how his family was doing and how he represented them in a negative space. But none of that felt offensive or scary.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was coming off rehab, so he was sober,‚Äù the source added. ‚ÄúThis was part of his path to recovery. His whole identity was being sober.‚Äù

In terms of the allegations that Nick murdered his parents, the insider said, ‚ÄúI am not that shocked. He is a troubled person. Nick had an aura of darkness around him with his addiction issues. When you have addiction and mental health, there is room for emotional murders ‚Ä¶ It doesn‚Äôt seem unfounded. He was a troubled kid from a young age and had issues. But that‚Äôs not the Nick I knew.‚Äù

A source told PEOPLE that Nick struggled to find his own identity in the shadow of his famous father and grandfather (Carl Reiner, who died in 2020).

‚ÄúNick wanted to live a life that didn‚Äôt exist. He was entitled,‚Äù the insider said. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt want to do any work but expected to be loved the way the rest of his family was.‚Äù The source added that Michele and Rob ‚Äúfelt enormous guilt for so long that they couldn‚Äôt help Nick get his life together ‚Ä¶ they could never reach stability with Nick. They tried everything‚Äîgiving him space, keeping him close‚Äîbut his struggles are so deep. It‚Äôs just a parent‚Äôs worst nightmare. They were such lovely people and tried in every way to help their son.‚Äù

Related: Does Nick Reiner Have Instagram? See the Private Account His Siblings Follow

What did Nick Reiner suffer from?

Nick struggled with mental illness and addiction for much of his life, TMZ reported which at times left him homeless and often in and out of various rehabilitation centers and programs; his count as of 2016 was reportedly 17 stints. His substance abuse, and his family‚Äôs responses to it, deteriorated his relationship with his parents. Sources alleged to TMZ that prescription drugs especially ‚Äúmessed with [Nick‚Äôs] head.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was homeless in Maine. I was homeless in New Jersey. I was homeless in Texas,‚Äù Nick told PEOPLE in 2016. ‚ÄúI spent nights on the street. I spent weeks on the street. It was not fun ‚Ä¶ If I wanted to do it my way and not go to the programs they were suggesting, then I had to be homeless.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen Nick would tell us that it wasn‚Äôt working for him, we wouldn‚Äôt listen,‚Äù Rob recalled to the Los Angeles Times in September 2015. ‚ÄúWe were desperate, and because the people had diplomas on their wall, we listened to them when we should have been listening to our son.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were so influenced by these people,‚Äù Michele added at the time. ‚ÄúThey would tell us he‚Äôs a liar, that he was trying to manipulate us. And we believed them.‚Äù

For his part, Nick said in a 2016 interview with Build Studios that he ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt really bond a lot‚Äù with his father when he was young. He also admitted (via the Los Angeles Times), ‚ÄúI had no identity, and I had no passions. I think the reason I had no identity was because I have a famous dad and a famous grandpa, and that fame sort of informs who you are. So I wanted to edge out my own identity with a more rebellious, angry, drug-addicted sort of persona.‚Äù

In 2018, Nick revealed that on the Dopey podcast that he‚Äôd once gotten so high that he completely trashed his parents‚Äô guest house.

‚ÄúI got totally spun out on uppers,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think it was coke and something else‚Äîand I was up for days on end. I started punching out different things in my guest house ‚Ä¶ started with the TV and then I went over to the lamp ‚Ä¶ everything in the guest house got wrecked.‚Äù

In September 2025, Rob told NPR that Nick was doing well and had been sober for about six years at that point in time.

Sources told PEOPLE that at O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs holiday party, ‚ÄúNick was freaking everyone out, acting crazy, kept asking people if they were famous.‚Äù According to TMZ, Nick arrived underdressed for the ‚Äúritzy‚Äù event (he wore a sweatshirt while everyone else wore suits and fancy dresses). Insiders alleged that he was behaving erratically, roaming around the property aimlessly and barely interacting with other guests. According to NBC News, one of those guests was Barry star and Saturday Night Live alum Bill Hader: Nick reportedly interrupted Hader during what Hader told him was a ‚Äúprivate conversation,‚Äù then stoood still, stared blankly and finally stormed off.

Sources alleged that Rob and Michele were embarrassed at Nick‚Äôs behavior at the party and that they‚Äôd ‚Äútried everything‚Äù to get their son to be healthy.

‚ÄúThey had had an argument at Conan‚Äôs holiday party, and Rob had been telling people that they‚Äôre scared for Nick and scared that his mental state was deteriorating,‚Äù a source told the New York Post. A friend of the Reiner family claimed that Rob and Michele were urging Nick to get treatment at a facility for a drug relapse, but that he refused.

Markowitz concurred that the Reiners worked extraordinarily hard to get Nick healthy.

‚ÄúThey gave him everything, they tried a million things with him,‚Äù he told Page Six. ‚ÄúNot giving him money but sending him to top-of-the-line places. Rob never gave up. He tried everything. If you knew Rob, he was just a bundle of love.‚Äù He added that he and Rob never suspected Nick could be violent with them, explaining, ‚Äú[Rob] never had fears for his safety. I‚Äôm not in his head, but we talked. [Nick] wasn‚Äôt a violent type. I slept in the same house as Nick. There was never a thought, I believe, in Rob‚Äôs head [that Nick was a danger]. If he would have thought his life was in peril at any point, he would have handled the situation.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúWhen somebody is mentally disturbed, you don‚Äôt need a reason. There‚Äôs no rhyme or reason. Mental illness, that‚Äôs the reason.‚Äù

However, a source told The Daily Mail that Nick‚Äôs family was ‚Äúscared‚Äù of him because of his alleged ‚Äúviolent outbursts,‚Äù and described Nick as ‚Äúviolent and super aggressive.‚Äù They claimed that his behavior was often disturbing, but was ‚Äúmagnified to horrific levels‚Äù when he was using substances. Sources alleged that Nick was a ‚Äúticking time bomb‚Äù and prone to ‚Äúmeth-fueled outbursts‚Äù that often included destroying property. An insider alleged that Rob and Michele ‚Äúthreatened to call authorities multiple times, but in the end didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they thought he was violent, things would have been very different,‚Äù a source told PEOPLE. ‚ÄúAt the worst of it, it hadn‚Äôt been like this. I don‚Äôt think anyone could have ever seen anything like this coming. Nick was declining lately but he had been really bad before.‚Äù

Related: Who Is Nick Reiner‚Äôs Defense Attorney Alan Jackson?

Is Being Charlie about Rob Reiner‚Äôs son?

When Nick got sober (at least at the time), he and Rob collaborated on the 2015 film Being Charlie. The movie was a semi-autobiographical look at a successful filmmaker eyeing a run for political office (played by Cary Elwes, who also starred in Reiner‚Äôs classic The Princess Bride) and his strained relationship with his son Charlie (Nick Robinson), who suffers from addiction.

Rob and Nick said that one particular line in the movie, when the father character tells his son, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather you hate me and be alive,‚Äù came directly from their real-life conversations.

‚ÄúI mean, we did get into fights over things, but ultimately it forced us to make the film better,‚Äù Rob Reiner said in 2016. ‚ÄúThe whole process for me‚ÄîI can just speak for myself‚Äîit did make me understand him a lot more, and it did make me a better father. Hopefully it did.‚Äù

Related: Watch Rob Reiner and Nick Reiner Talk About Being Charlie a Decade Before the Director‚Äôs Murder

How old is Nick Reiner?

Born Sept. 14, 1993, Nick Reiner is 32 years old as of this writing.

Has Nick Reiner been arrested?

Nick Reiner was arrested without incident at about 9:15 p.m. PT on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025, hours after his parents were found dead.

Related: LAPD Releases Photos of Nick Reiner‚Äôs Arrest

Where was Nick Reiner found?

Police arrested Nick Reiner close to Exposition Park and near the University of Southern California campus, PEOPLE reported. Footage obtained by ABC7 Eyewitness News showed that Nick bought a drink at a gas station moments before police apprehended him. He was wearing a black, green and white striped track jacket, a black cap and blue jeans and was carrying a red backpack at the time.

TMZ reported that Nick had checked into the Pierside Santa Monica hotel, 20 miles from where he was arrested, at about 4 a.m. on Dec. 14, 2025, using his credit card. Spies alleged that Nick was ‚Äútweaked out‚Äù when he checked in, but that he didn‚Äôt have any blood visible on his person. His room after he left, however, was a horrifyingly different story: Police who went to the room to investigate reportedly found blood in the shower and on the bed and bedsheets covering the windows.

Sources told TMZ that police told front desk staff at the hotel they were there to do a welfare check on Nick, and ultimately performed a search for the murder weapon on the premises.

TMZ later obtained footage of Nick walking towards the hotel minutes before he checked in (and hours before Rob and Michele Singer Reiner‚Äôs bodies were found in their home). In this footage, Nick carries a black backpack, not a red one like he did when he was arrested, so it appears he switched bags at some point after getting to his hotel room and before police apprehended him.

Related: Rob Reiner‚Äôs When Harry Met Sally Confession Goes Viral After His and Wife Michele‚Äôs Death

What is Nick Reiner charged with?

On Tuesday, Dec. 16, 2025, Nick Reiner was formally charged with two counts of first-degree murder for the deaths of Michele and Rob Reiner. Assistant district attorney Nathan J. Hochman said in a statement that the charges carry a maximum sentence of life without parole or the death penalty.

Because there were multiple murders, Nick was hit with additional special circumstances, which can add extra time to a prison sentence.

‚ÄúProsecuting these cases involving family members are some of the most challenging and most heart wrenching cases that this office faces because of the intimate and often brutal nature of the crimes involved,‚Äù Hochman said.

Related: Rob Reiner‚Äôs Daughter Tracy Reiner Speaks Out After His Death: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm in Shock‚Äô

What is Nick Reiner‚Äôs bail?

Nick‚Äôs bail was set at $4 million, but he is now being held without bail at the Twin Towers Correctional Facility.

Related: Michelle Obama Reveals She and Barack Had Plans With Rob and Michele Reiner the Day They Died

When is Nick Reiner‚Äôs court appearance?

Nick appeared in court briefly on Wednesday, Dec. 17, 2025, TMZ reported. He was seated behind glass and did not enter a plea. His attorney, Alan Jackson, said that the court agreed to formally arraign Nick on Jan. 7, 2025. According to PEOPLE, when asked if he waived his right to a speedy arraignment, Nick replied, ‚ÄúYes, your honor.‚Äù He reportedly wore a suicide prevention vest to court.

PEOPLE previously reported that Jackson told press that Nick Reiner hadn‚Äôt been medically cleared to appear in court and that it was a ‚Äúprocedural issue.‚Äù

On Tuesday, Dec. 16, 2025, Hochman said that once Nick had a medical screening, he would be formally arraigned in court.
news.author: Jessica Sager

news.title: Prediction Markets and the ‚ÄòSuckerifcation‚Äô Crisis, With Max Read
news.text:
Subscribe here: Apple Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube 

In this episode of Galaxy Brain, Charlie Warzel explores the burgeoning industry of prediction markets. These platforms let people wager on everything from elections and award shows to the most trivial internet ephemera, framing bets as tradable ‚Äúshares‚Äù that rise and fall like stocks. With billions in weekly trading volume, massive new funding rounds, and even a CNN partnership with the prediction-betting platform, Kalshi, prediction markets are quickly moving from niche curiosity to mainstream-media fixture‚Äîopenly touting ambitions to financialize everything.

Warzel is joined by writer Max Read, who argues that prediction markets sit at the intersection of gambling, finance, and a broader ‚Äúsuckerification‚Äù economy aimed at young men. Together they unpack whether the markets actually reflect the ‚Äúwisdom of crowds‚Äù or whether they‚Äôre little more than a meta-game of vibes, ideology, and misvalued dumb money. The pair explore the culture of these platforms and offer a diagnosis of the attention economy: When it‚Äôs hard to sell anything directly, it‚Äôs easier to sell derivatives of everything. Prediction markets may promise clarity, Warzel and Read suggest, but what they really offer is another way to feel excitement in a world that feels rigged.

The following is a transcript of the episode:

Max Read: When I say a ‚Äúsuckerification crisis,‚Äù I don‚Äôt simply mean, Oh, you know, they‚Äôre getting bilked out of their money, though I think that‚Äôs part of it. I think there‚Äôs a whole kind of both commercial and political kind of apparatus that is working really hard to separate young guys from their money.

Charlie Warzel: I am Charlie Warzel, and this is Galaxy Brain. A few weeks ago on this podcast, the journalist Pablo Torre told me this.

Pablo Torre: It feels like, you know, we‚Äôre living at a time in which lots of young people were promised things they were not delivered. Perhaps because of the generations that continued to wield power in our government, economy, et cetera, the Boomers‚Äîand the way to, like, Chutes and Ladders your way to the American dream is gambling on shit. And in that casino premise, I think you just see again a through line across all these sectors of American life now. Sports being one that has so naturally taken to it. Because, my gosh, here‚Äôs an unlimited menu. I mean, literally.

Warzel: Today we‚Äôre going to explore another part of that unlimited menu of gambling in the casino-ification of the American economy: prediction markets. Chances are you‚Äôve been hearing a lot about prediction markets lately. At their core, prediction markets are online spaces where people can place wagers on the outcome of events.

They share similarities with sports books except, unlike a traditional bed at a casino, your wager is a futures contract‚Äîthe value of which fluctuates based on the market value of the outcome of any given event. Right now, people use the markets to bet on sports, events like the Oscars, whether Elon Musk will tweet a specific number of times in a given month, or about the outcome of an election.

The top platforms now for prediction markets collectively report several billion dollars‚Äô worth of weekly trading volume. Kalshi, one of the biggest prediction markets in this space, announced this month that it raised a billion dollars from many of Silicon Valley‚Äôs biggest venture-capital firms.

Recently, CNN announced it was partnering with Kalshi to integrate the company‚Äôs prediction-market data in the news coverage. The company‚Äôs CEO, Tarek Mansour, has big ambitions. At a conference in October, he said this about Kalshi‚Äôs future:

Tarek Mansour: The long-term vision is to financialize everything and create a tradable asset out of any difference in opinion.

Warzel: ‚ÄúFinancialize everything.‚Äù

That‚Äôs essentially the quiet part out loud. That is the blueprint for the actual casinoification of the world, brought to you by one of the more ascendant companies that‚Äôs moving everything toward gambling. So what‚Äôs really going on here? How do prediction markets work? Is there some truth to what boosters allege: that people putting their money where their mouths are is actually a good way to tap into the wisdom of crowds?

Or is this just a dystopian development? An example of companies preying on a society with a burgeoning gambling addiction? Today I am joined by Max Read, author of the Great Substack Read Max. Read covers culture and power on the internet and has this really intuitive understanding of platforms and people.

Recently he wrote a great piece titled ‚ÄúPrediction Markets and the Suckerification Crisis.‚Äù Max and I talk about where all this is going and why everyone is gambling and no one is happy. Now, my conversation with Max Read.

Warzel: Max Read, welcome to Galaxy Brain.

Read: Thanks for having me, Charlie.

Warzel: Yeah. So we‚Äôre going to talk about prediction markets. Hopefully come up with some grand theory as to why they are ascendant and why everything feels a little bit broken. But I want to just first‚Äîfor the normies out there who aren‚Äôt, you know, using them.

How would you describe them? How are they different from straight-up gambling or a sports book?

Read: Yeah, well, the first time I wrote about them, I described them as sports books that allowed you to place wagers on non-sports events. But I think the extra sort of bit that‚Äôs important to understand about them‚Äîbecause at the end of the day, that is what they are, and it‚Äôs the way a lot of people use them. And I should note, by the way, that when I say they‚Äôre not: They‚Äôre sports books that allow you to place bets on non-sporting events. Many of them are actually also sports books. Kalshi in particular allows you to place wagers on games.

But what they do is really emphasize the wager as a security that you can purchase and sell the way you would a share on the stock market, say. So if you believed, say, that there would be a Democratic sweep across New Jersey, Virginia, and New York City back in November, you could have bought shares. Or you could have bet on that outcome for, you know, what, like 30‚Äîlike, they‚Äôll do it as prices, right? You bet, you wager 30 cents for the return of a dollar, right? So you could buy the shares at 30 cents. You buy 10 shares at 30 cents; you get $10 back. If that comes off.

Now, I mentioned 30 cents, say, because a couple weeks‚ÄîI‚Äôm not sure if that‚Äôs the exact price‚Äîbut a couple weeks before this election, it was kind of unclear what Democrats‚Äô chances were going to be in any of these elections. There‚Äôs a lot of polls coming out saying that Mikie Sherrill in New Jersey was running dangerously sort of close in the race against ‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt even remember the name of her opponent at this point.

But, you know, it was a fairly low probability according to the betters on the app. Right? But as the returns start to come in on Tuesday night‚Äîand it becomes clear that actually the chances that this is going to be a sweep across all these elections get higher‚Äîall of a sudden the price of a given wager rises. Or the price of a given share, so to speak.

So at 30 cents‚Äîsuddenly it‚Äôs 40 cents, suddenly it‚Äôs 60 cents. The way you would think about that if you were just talking gambling odds is, all of a sudden, you‚Äôre getting less return on your wager, basically. Your odds are getting significantly easier.

And, you could have, say‚Äîlet me give a slightly different example of election. So recently in Tennessee, this woman, Aftyn Behn, was running for a congressional seat. And, she was absolutely not the favorite. It was a ‚ÄúTrump plus 30‚Äù congressional district or whatever, and you could buy shares for her victory at like, you know, 20 cents, something like that, the week before the election. The night of the election, as returns start coming in, she‚Äôs looking actually kind of good for it. The early returns are quite good for her. And I watched as the price of her shares climbed up. I‚Äôm not going to say whether or not I had any horse in this race, any money on this. But I was watching it closely, let‚Äôs just say.

And there was a point where if you had bought shares at 30‚Äîand again, who knows who I‚Äôm talking about here‚Äîbut if you had bought shares at 30, you could have sold them for a 100 percent profit. Sold them at 60 cents. Only for those shares to come crashing down as the results continue coming over the night, and it becomes clear it‚Äôs not happening.

So‚Äîsorry, this is a sort of complicated explanation‚Äîbut I think it‚Äôs useful to understand how you use it. Right? That when you go on these sites, what you‚Äôre doing is: You‚Äôre doing this kind of thing that‚Äôs kind of a hybrid. Like stock-market day-trading activity and a betting activity. And I do think it‚Äôs worth saying, as much as they emphasize the sort of security, quality of these wagers.

You can do this at a sports book too, right? That odds will change at a sports book depending on who‚Äôs taking which side of the bet, and you can cash out. Most sports books will allow you to cash out various times, you know, after you‚Äôve placed your wager. And if the odds of the wager have changed in between the period where you placed your wager and you‚Äôre cashing out, you could make a small profit just from cashing out, right?

If you wager a team is going to win, and then you could cash out with five minutes to go and they‚Äôre up by 20 points, you‚Äôre not going to get as much as you would if you saw the whole thing out. But you can cash out at a fairly high profit. So in that sense, you know, it‚Äôs sort of another way of looking at, or another way of thinking about, gambling that emphasizes the sort of up-and-down nature of odds. And I think that‚Äôs how most people kind of approach it when they‚Äôre on the site placing these wagers‚Äîthey‚Äôre thinking about it like betting. But I think it‚Äôs also important to understand why [these sites] have become so ubiquitous in media is that they are exciting to a lot of economists and libertarians. especially libertarian economists. It‚Äôs that they offer a kind of semi-accurate‚Äîaccurate depending on the liquidity of the market, accurate depending on the size of the market‚Äîaccurate picture of what you might think of as the conventional wisdom. Right? Because there‚Äôs all these people collectively saying how much [they‚Äôre] placing their own odds, so to speak, on a given outcome.

Wagering their own actual money, so they have skin in the game. So nobody‚Äôs doing this just for propaganda purposes, or whatever. You can say, Conventional wisdom has the chances of this event happening at 50 percent, 30 percent, whatever. Now, these markets are still fairly small, and many of them are not very liquid at all.

So it is not like there‚Äôs millions of people betting a couple bucks at a time to make them, you know, as sort of accurate as possible. You‚Äôll have a couple whales who are placing large wagers, which makes them interesting in what they tell you. Because it‚Äôs not saying, necessarily, the conventional wisdom according to the kind of person who places a bet on this kind of a thing.

But that‚Äôs the other side of it. The nonuser side, the media side, the philosophical side of this is: Prediction markets allow us to start to look at the future in this way that allows us to set probabilities about things.

Warzel: I‚Äôm curious what you make of the ‚Äúwisdom of crowds‚Äù bit, because this is the part of me that stops and feels a little insane sometimes with this. Because I think about, like, this is essentially a meta-game, right? Where you have this system that produces outcomes and incentives for certain outcomes that arise in it, and you wrap that system in an apparatus that is also concerned with influencing those outcomes.

It‚Äôs this second-order thing like you have with poker‚Äîwhere good poker players can technically predict the outcome of hands, but that is also influencing the outcomes of the games. It just feels to me like what you‚Äôre doing is: Prediction markets aren‚Äôt what people think will happen. It‚Äôs what people think other people think will happen, right? So it feels to me it‚Äôs confusing.

Read: I do think there‚Äôs a use for that. You could come up with reasons. And from a financial sort of market perspective, one way of thinking about it is that these are effectively tools. Instruments for hedging, right?

That you have a sense of‚Äîyou think something‚Äôs going to happen, but you also want to place some wagers on the side in case it doesn‚Äôt happen to limit your losses. And for that, you don‚Äôt need it to be wholly accurate, right? You just need it to sort of approximate a given outcome that allows you to make money off of that.

I think there‚Äôs sort of two ways to go with what you‚Äôre saying. One is that, until recently, prediction markets have largely been a sort of theoretical idea, right? I mean, we could talk about the stock market‚Äîor a sports book, for that matter‚Äîas a prediction market. But this sort of all-encompassing marketplace to make wagers on.

I mean, recently there were wagers on the Time magazine ‚ÄúPerson of the Year‚Äù cover, all the Oscars, all the award-season stuff. You can wager on who‚Äôs going to get nominated and who‚Äôs going to win. We‚Äôve talked about elections already. There‚Äôs even, often, marketplaces for words getting mentioned by prominent figures in‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the word I‚Äôm looking for‚Äîin speeches or in, you know, earnings calls. If you believe really strongly in the idea of the wisdom of crowds, it‚Äôs very exciting.

But the theoretical model of the prediction market is, as I was sort of emphasizing before, is one that everybody is participating in. The market is fully liquid. Everybody has a stake in it. Everybody is placing wagers there. And these markets are fairly far from that, right? On Election Night, there tends to be enough money, and enough people, to sort of approximate what we‚Äôve been talking about as the conventional wisdom about who‚Äôs going to win and who‚Äôs going to lose.

But that‚Äôs not always the case, and certainly not the case for stuff like these culture categories that I‚Äôm talking about. I wanted to ask‚Äîwithout you having to divulge whether you are, or are not, actively participating in these markets‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the culture like on these? I think it mirrors some of the culture on X/Twitter in the Musk era.

But when you go either to try to place some wagers, or for reporting purposes,what‚Äôs the culture like?

Read: So, I can talk about the culture in the comment sections‚Äîwhich I wouldn‚Äôt want to suggest is wholly reflective of the culture of these places in general.

And I think there is a wide range. There is smart money. There are sharks out there who are running programs and bots to identify. Especially on an election night, you‚Äôll get guys who are pulling results all doing this automated, basically HFD‚Äîlike high-frequency traders pulling results from The New York Times or Decision Desk or whoever. And, like, immediately placing orders on shares to take advantage of that. Like, you don‚Äôt have to do it in the milliseconds the way you do on Wall Street, but you can do it if you just do it in a couple seconds. We‚Äôll still make it advantageous.

And you have people who are quite good‚Äîfor example, the Time magazine cover leaked before it was announced. And a bunch of people made a tidy little profit, because it took a while for the market to catch up. So I say that just to say that there are smart people. Just as a to be sure thing before I get into the comments‚Äîwhich are really stupid. I mean, there‚Äôs just a lot of stupid people there. And there‚Äôs a funny mix of just really obviously stupid people‚Äîyou know, Free Republic‚Äìcommenter type, X, like bottom-of-the-barrel, Trumpist X types. And then there‚Äôs stupid, just guys who have sort of wandered in. Every wager, if you scroll far enough, you‚Äôll find a guy who took the stupid side of the wager because he didn‚Äôt read the terms until after he‚Äôd put his $50 down.

He is like, Oh, I didn‚Äôt realize that I was actually betting, you know, against this. I thought I was betting for it. Oh, well, now I‚Äôm out 50 bucks. The tone reminds me a lot of‚ÄîI think the closest thing I can think of online, or the two closest things, are the: If you play fantasy football in Yahoo, every player has their own little comment section. And you can pull it up as you‚Äôre deciding who‚Äôs to start and who to bench.

And it‚Äôs just filled with people just clinging to the most desperate of threads. You know, citing articles they read somewhere. Nobody‚Äôs linking to anything. Everyone‚Äôs like, Oh, I heard he is going to play. Oh, I heard he is injured. Oh, I heard he‚Äôs, you know, he‚Äôs not going to be the first QB.

He‚Äôs not going to get any catches. He is not going to get any throws this game. Whatever it is. And the comments on the bets kind of remind me of this on all the markets. It‚Äôs somebody being like, Oh, you know, there‚Äôs one market that‚Äôs which member of Trump‚Äôs Cabinet is going to leave first.

And everyone‚Äôs like, Well, okay, well here‚Äôs this thing I read about [Pete] Hegseth. And somebody else will be like, Well, I read this about Pam Bondi. And people doing their theories. It‚Äôs a message board. It‚Äôs not the dumbest place I‚Äôve ever read, but it‚Äôs of a basic kind of politics message-board stupidity.

And every dispute is going to be financialized, and we‚Äôre going to figure that out.

It‚Äôs more like: I just wanna take a little risk somewhere. Like, a fairly safe risk. Just to give myself ‚Ä¶ just to feel something, somewhere. Just to feel something.

Warzel: The thing that makes me think about with sports‚Äîespecially in baseball, where we‚Äôre about to go into, a year from now, these major labor disputes with the unions‚Äîis this inequality, right? There is this fundamental inequality in baseball between the haves and the have-nots. And the big-market teams and the Cincinnati Reds. Or like, you know, what have you. And in that, you do have that situation often in a fanbase of Okay, well, if we make the playoffs, we‚Äôre going to get, you know, absolutely destroyed in the first round. And that‚Äôs a good year. And ‚Äúenjoy the ride,‚Äù right? But it‚Äôs getting something else there. And then when I try to think‚Äîdoes that apply broadly out to politics?

Of course, maybe not exactly, right? It‚Äôs not a total inequality thing. But it is this sort of feeling like the system isn‚Äôt going to move, right? Like it‚Äôs sclerotic in this way. Like you‚Äôre not going to get a candidate that‚Äôs just going to come out of nowhere, unless you have, you know, these instances like Mamdani.

Read: I mean, look at how much energy, I mean, even Kamala Harris‚Äôs emergence‚Äîin 18 hours as the Democratic nominee, after [Joe] Biden [dropped out], had that burst of energy. Because it was such an unexpected historical event. Even if she was, you know, not the most exciting candidate to young people in the world, or whatever. She was a sort of‚Äîexactly who you would‚Äôve ‚Äúexpect the unexpectedness‚Äù about. It gave that extra bit of energy.

Warzel: I think that that is such a good way to frame all of this in a world that‚Äôs feeling a little bit locked, right? Where everything seems a little locked, this is injecting a kind of chaos that allows people to feel.

Read: I think that‚Äôs real. Well, the other thing‚Äîand I would say two things on top of that. One is: I think‚Äîjust to reconnect some of the stuff we were talking about before‚ÄîI think it is relatively similar to some of the appeal of social networks, which have a volatility to them. And I think that one of the reasons that Twitter is less‚Äîand Facebook too, are less and less, and Instagram even‚Äîbecome less and less interesting to people is probably because they become sort of solved games. And, you know, what does well in the algorithm. What does well. It‚Äôs much harder to have that pop of the thing that you get really early on a social network‚Äîalways like, I‚Äôve never seen something like this before. This is so weird. This kind of person, you could still sort of find it there. But those that like volatility, it‚Äôs there in a certain limited way. But not in the same way. The other thing, I would say, is that this feeling we‚Äôre talking about‚ÄîI think what‚Äôs at stake is a sense that there‚Äôs very little to surprise us anymore.

And this is, again, a sort of a vibe more than it is a fact. But there is this vibe of, like, Everything‚Äôs optimized to hell. Everybody, for the most part, acts really cautious in their given settings, the domains in which they‚Äôre playing. It‚Äôs hard to find surprise. Gambling at least gives us some level of, you know‚Äîallows us to feel something, as we put it.

But what prediction markets effectively do, over the long term, is even eliminate that from gambling. Because what you‚Äôre doing‚Äîonce the market is big enough, once enough people are betting‚Äîall of a sudden all the surprises are kind of gone. Except for weather events, right?

It‚Äôs the last thing that you could bet on: where there‚Äôs some possibly there won‚Äôt be rain, despite the 90 percent‚Äìchance forecast the next day. And I think it‚Äôs self-defeating. I suppose. I don‚Äôt like ‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a science-fiction story more than it is something that we really have to worry about at this point.

But I think that ultimately the point of the prediction market is to reassert the primacy of locked-in predictions. Even if what makes it interesting right now is the enjoyment of risk and novelty and surprise.

Warzel: I love the idea that eventually the prediction market, it eats its own young at the end of it. I think that‚Äôs a great place to leave it. Max Read, thank you so much for coming on Galaxy Brain.

Read: It was absolutely my pleasure. Thanks for this great conversation.

Warzel: That‚Äôs it for us here. Thank you again to my guest, Max Read. If you liked what you saw here, new episodes of Galaxy Brain drop every Friday. You can subscribe to The Atlantic‚Äôs YouTube channel, or on Apple or Spotify or wherever you get your podcasts. And if you enjoyed this, remember: You can support our work and the work of all the journalists at The Atlantic by subscribing to the publication TheAtlantic.com/Listener.

That‚Äôs TheAtlantic.com/Listener. Thanks so much. I‚Äôll see you on the internet.
news.author: Charlie Warzel

news.title: How Bad Is It for Dems? Their Decision on Releasing Their 2024 Autopsy Report Says It All
news.text:
As we reported, new polling brought some bad news for congressional Democrats. 

They hit their lowest rating ever, with only 18 percent approval, 73 percent disapproval in a new Quinnipiac poll.

As CNN data guru Harry Enten explained, they were "-55 net approval, an all-time low & lower than the Dead Sea." 

What was worse for them was that even amongst their own party, they were underwater, with only 42 percent approving and 48 percent disapproving. Their party approval had taken a nosedive since October, after they failed in the government shutdown fight. 

Despite that, they were ahead on the generic ballot by about four points. But as Enten noted, this should be much higher normally for the midterms, where the party out of power usually has the advantage. It showed how weak they were. 

READ MORE: Make It Make Sense: Dem Approval Rating Falls Off a Cliff, but Voters Have Baffling Reaction

Now, on Friday, two new polls, Emerson and Quantus Insights, show Democrats only up by two points in the generic ballot, which is even better than the numbers Enten had mentioned. Quantus has it at 43 to 41 percent, and Emerson has it at 44 to 42 percent. 

Then, on top of that, the DNC's Ken Martin announced that they wouldn't be releasing the autopsy report on why they lost in 2024. 

Ken Martin, the chairman of the D.N.C., said on Thursday that he had decided not to publish a report that he ordered months ago into what went wrong for the Democratic Party last year. Party officials have conducted more than 300 interviews with Democrats in all 50 states to create a document that Mr. Martin had once pitched as crucial to charting a path forward. Mr. Martin will instead keep the findings under seal. He believes that looking back so publicly and painfully at the past would prove counterproductive for the party as it tries next year to take back power in Congress, according to a D.N.C. spokeswoman who spoke on the condition of anonymity to share the thinking behind his decision. ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs our North Star: Does this help us win?‚Äù Mr. Martin said in a statement. ‚ÄúIf the answer is no, it‚Äôs a distraction from the core mission.‚Äù

Translation? The report shows how bad their issues are; it will hurt and embarrass them. So, like typical Democrats, they just wasted all that time and money because they don't like the reality of what they were told. 

They haven't answered the question, for example, of how Kamala Harris' team threw $1.5 billion down the sewer and didn't even manage to win one swing state. 

Simon Bazelon, a Democratic researcher, noted how this decision doesn't help them solve their issues and was "reflective of a broader problem within the party." You can say that again. This is "hide your head in the sand" behavior. 

They appear to want to return to their strategy of 2024, just yelling about President Donald Trump. 

Republicans have a real chance here; they need to focus on the economy. They need to remind everyone what a mess things were under the Democrats, going up to 9 percent on inflation, and what they are doing to make things better, as Trump did during his economic address on Wednesday. 

READ MORE: Trump White House Address Touts Administration's Domestic Wins, Announces Christmas Bonus for Troops

Thursday's inflation number was good, at 2.7 percent. Gas is down, wages are up, and more good things are on the horizon. Keep focusing on making things better and getting that message out there.

news.title: CNN analyst delivers shocker! Dem Party‚Äôs approval never ‚Äòin worse shape‚Äô
news.text:
For those who have been watching the antics of a flailing Democrat Party since Kamala Harris and Tim Walz, who now is caught up in a billion dollar fraud scheme that has developed in his state, ever since they lost the 2024 presidential race to President Donald Trump, this might not be a surprise.

But to those who adhere to the left‚Äôs faith program that all is good in the Democrat Party and it is just a whisker from victory, it might me.

It is CNN‚Äôs chief data analyst that has confirmed the Democrat Party‚Äôs approval has declined, and pollsters now are finding that they‚Äôve never seen it ‚Äúin worse shape.‚Äù

Harry Enten‚Äôs conclusion? ‚ÄúLower than the Dead Sea.‚Äù

A report in Newsweek said, ‚ÄúMaintaining a strong approval rating will be of utmost importance to the party as it heads toward the midterm elections. The GOP has a slim majority of 219 to 214 in the House of Representatives and holds a 53-47 majority in the Senate so Democrats are looking to pick up key seats and gain control of Congress.‚Äù

Enten said, ‚ÄòDemocrats in the minds of the American public are lower than the Dead Sea‚Ä¶‚Äù

pic.twitter.com/rvPkh1FYDC 
NEW: CNN'S HARRY ENTEN
"Democrats, in the minds of the American public, are lower than the Dead Sea."@DailyCaller
‚Äî Jason Cohen (@JasonJournoDC) December 18, 2025

He cited polling from Quinnipiac University that has ‚Äúnever found Democrats, at least those in Congress, in worse shape than they are right now.‚Äù

In October, the Democrats were at plus 22, but now they are at minus 6, a plunge of 28 points, he said. Some of that was from negative perspectives from independents, but it‚Äôs also coming from Democrats themselves, he said.

One bright spot has been a couple of Democrat election wins in this off-off-year, such as the New York city mayor‚Äôs race.

The Newsweek report detailed: ‚ÄúThe Quinnipiac University national poll of registered voters found that 18 percent approved of the way the Democrats in Congress were handling their job‚Äî73 percent disapproved, which according to the pollster is a record low job approval rating for them.

The assessment contacted 1,035 self-identified registered voters nationwide form Dec. 11-15. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.9 percentage points.

American commentator Benny Johnson concluded, ‚ÄúHoly smokes it‚Äôs so over. CNN just dropped devastating news for Democrats‚Äù

Republicans pointed out, ‚ÄúPolling shows even Democrats hate Democrats!‚Äù
news.summary: Harry Enten says it's ‚Äòlower than the Dead Sea‚Äô

news.title: Jasmine Crocket Would Make Kamala Harris Proud With Her Latest Word Salad
news.text:
Representative Jasmine Crockett of Texas, who has begun her campaign trail, gave an answer in an interview that would have made Kamala Harris proud when asked to clarify her stance on reparations.

"I'm gonna try to get through these quickly," the interviewer began. "There's misinformation going around about your stance on reparations. I guess it's based off of, some would propose what we do with tax dollars, and you gave critique for the idea, but you weren't necessarily saying you were anti-reparations. And you've told me you've become the lead on a couple projects..."

"Yes, yes," Corckett replied. "Like Truth and Reconciliation in the House, that's something that Barbara Lee was working on. I think that anybody that knows me, knows that, um, I'm a fan of, you know, making sure that people understand our contributions as well as acknowledging the harm, um, that has happened as relates to our people. And so, um, for me, it's always been about what is it that we can actually get passed, because I feel like what we do is we constantly have the conversation and we're like, reparations, reparations, but it's like, alright, so if we were to move forward anyway, what does that look like?"

And so, um, you know, I look at it like, I think it takes kind of some bold, unapologetic people to move the needle. We know that Donald Trump advocated for reparations for January sixers, right? And so it's like, why is that not a big controversy, right? Like that's a bit more controversial, in my mind, right? Um, so why is it that we can sit here and be okay with the fact that billionaires are going to get historic tax cuts that are permanent, and we're not talking about really evaluating what could move the needle as it relates to how far behind we got, because of our contributions basically just from slave labor, and yeah, so...

üö®NEW: Jasmine Crockett gives WORD SALAD while failing to clarify her reparations stanceüö®@DailyCaller pic.twitter.com/z3IixgZ46f‚Äî Jason Cohen üá∫üá∏ (@JasonJournoDC) December 19, 2025

Crockett, facing the likely loss of her House seat under Texas‚Äôs new congressional map, announced earlier this month that she would run for the U.S. Senate, a move widely seen as likely to fail in the solidly red state, where Democrats haven't won in three decades.
